what my data science Master did not teach me

all_paragraphs: After I published my article about my switch from Business Development to Data Science and my article regarding what my data science Master did not teach me, many people reached out to me for advice about their own career switch. Some of them were worried about their ability to transition to Data Science while others asked about which online course was the best. While I obviously do not have all the answers, I thought I would share my own experience on the topic and a few pieces of advice for people looking to make such a change in their career.

In my opinion and experience, if your background is extremely disconnected from Data Science (just like mine was), online courses are simply not enough. The knowledge most online courses provide is useful, valuable, and represents a nice addition to your LinkedIn profile. However, I believe that most online courses do not cover enough real business problems to make you an appealing data scientist that will know what to do when facing issues with real messy, unreliable or hard to access data.

While I have started a few online courses in the past, I was never blown away by the quality of a course enough to name it and recommend it to everyone. It might just be that I lack the discipline to watch video after video for hours. In any case, I do not want to mention specific online courses but I would like to highlight what you should look into when choosing an online course.

I do not have a miracle solution. What works for one person might not work for the other. I also do not know whether markets and demands regarding experience vary strongly from a country to another. However, I have many colleagues, friends and acquaintances from different background who ended up in data science through common paths.
Traineeships often open many doors to an environment where you can learn fast and (often) be paid while learning.

Investing in the right internship in the right company can have a huge impact on your career. The right company, to me, is defined as a company that focuses on the learning potential of their interns and provides a supportive culture of knowledge sharing. Both traineeships and internships allow you to learn from seniors in the field, which in my opinion, is the best kind of learning.

Companies aim at finding candidates that can think like a data scientist and consequently like a programmer. They want to see that you have previously been able to solve issues with data and code, even if what you have built only helped in your personal tasks (think about a forecasting tool for your monthly expenses or an app to predict the score of football matches). It also gives you content to talk about in a job interview.

When you come from a business background or any other extremely different domain, such career switch requires hard work, many hours of studying, trying to figure out why your code is not working or searching for an explanation to an inconsistency in your data.

Learning Data Science and good programming requires a very steep learning curve and any slow learner will have a very hard time making the switch. It is not easy, and it can be frustrating as hell so before investing months of your life in it, make sure that you REALLY want to be a data scientist. The name sounds somehow sexy, the pay can be good (not everywhere..) but the work can be tedious, full of political issues, and rather boring when it comes to bug fixing. You also need to constantly keep learning since the field moves so fast and while many people love learning, constant change does not fit everyone.
In Data Science, the more you learn, the more you realize how much you do NOT know.

When someone asks me if they think it can be done, I cannot give them a definite answer. It depends on how hard they can and are willing to work, how resilient they can be and also, on the availability of learning resources. Nonetheless, whether someone can become a data scientist or not, I do believe that the data science knowledge someone has gathered will benefit them in the future, to understand the technology we live with a bit better, and to turn their career a little more towards a domain they are passionate about.
